issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When a user changes its password from inside the GUI there is no required sign
out. Another user could be currently logged in with a valid session using what
are now invalidated credentials. This user continues to have access to the UI
until its session is invalidated. The real world situation would be if someone
was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account due to termination
and the password had to be changed. If this user still had a session open on
its browser it would still be able to configure parts of the system including
policies and account access.
fields.summary: Dashboard: On reset of password once logged in, all sessions for that user should be invalidated

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2011-07-27 17:15:46 by viglesias

Wed Jul 27 10:15:45 2011: Request 2951 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by vic.iglesias
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: Dashboard: On reset of password once logged in, all sessions for
 that user should be invalidated
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: vic.iglesias@eucalyptus.com
Organization: Eucalyptus Systems
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2951 >


When a user changes its password from inside the GUI there is no required sign
out. Another user could be currently logged in with a valid session using what
are now invalidated credentials. This user continues to have access to the UI
until its session is invalidated. The real world situation would be if someone
was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account due to termination
and the password had to be changed. If this user still had a session open on
its browser it would still be able to configure parts of the system including
policies and account access.

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 17:18:41 by wenye
Good point.

On Wed, Jul 27, 2011 at 10:15 AM, Victor Iglesias via RT <
bugs@support.eucalyptus.com> wrote:

are now invalidated credentials. This user continues to have access to the UI
until its session is invalidated. The real world situation would be if someone
was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account due to termination
and the password had to be changed. If this user still had a session open on
its browser it would still be able to configure parts of the system including

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 17:25:24 by rusvika
That's a very good catch! This is a big security problem if a session id of a
user is stolen. In this case, if all sessions for this account are not
invalidated, the password change will not prevent the attacker from using the
account (and, as I understand, in our design, not all accounts/users can be
deleted).

To prevent this situation, on a password change, the current user's session
could simply get a new session id and all other user's session should be
invalidated.

  
On Wed Jul 27 10:15:45 2011, vic.iglesias wrote:

> When a user changes its password from inside the GUI there is no

> required sign

> out. Another user could be currently logged in with a valid session

> using what

> are now invalidated credentials. This user continues to have access to

> the UI

> until its session is invalidated. The real world situation would be if

> someone

> was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account due to

> termination

> and the password had to be changed. If this user still had a session

> open on

> its browser it would still be able to configure parts of the system

> including

> policies and account access.

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 17:25:25 by rusvika

<URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2951 >

That's a very good catch! This is a big security problem if a session id of a
user is stolen. In this case, if all sessions for this account are not
invalidated, the password change will not prevent the attacker from using the
account (and, as I understand, in our design, not all accounts/users can be
deleted).
To prevent this situation, on a password change, the current user's session
could simply get a new session id and all other user's session should be
invalidated.

That's a very good catch! This is a big security problem if a session id of a
user is stolen. In this case, if all sessions for this account are not
invalidated, the password change will not prevent the attacker from using the
account (and, as I understand, in our design, not all accounts/users can be

someone > was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account due to >

session > open on > its browser it would still be able to configure parts of
the system > including > policies and account access.

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 20:05:47 by tjcramer
Hold on though! In large enterprises its customary to have a forced change of
password every 6 months. If this were enforced and the user had jobs running,
they would all be invalidated and they would be pretty upset. We should find
out if there's some other standard for this kind of behavior before we make a
change like this.

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 20:15:23 by rusvika
It looks like there was a misunderstanding. By the "session" here, we mean a
web session ID, which should expire upon the password change so that a user
with an old session id could not keep using web interface without providing
the new password. This session invalidation should not affect any other user
jobs (like running instances and such).

This session invalidation should not affect any other user > jobs > (like
running instances and such). > > On Wed Jul 27 13:05:47 2011, tim.cramer
wrote: > > Hold on though! In large enterprises its customary to have a forced
> > change of > > password every 6 months. If this were enforced and the user
had jobs > > running, > > they would all be invalidated and they would be
pretty upset. We > > should find > > out if there's some other standard for
this kind of behavior before we > > make a > > change like this. > > > > > > >
> On Wed Jul 27 10:25:24 2011, vika.felmetsger wrote: > > > That's a very good
catch! This is a big security problem if a > > session > > > id of a > > >
user is stolen. In this case, if all sessions for this account are > > not > >
> invalidated, the password change will not prevent the attacker from > > >
using the > > > account (and, as I understand, in our design, not all
accounts/users > > > can be > > > deleted). > > > To prevent this situation,
on a password change, the current user's > > > session > > > could simply get
a new session id and all other user's session > > should > > > be > > >
invalidated. > > > > > > On Wed Jul 27 10:15:45 2011, vic.iglesias wrote: > >
> > When a user changes its password from inside the GUI there is no > > > >
required sign > > > > out. Another user could be currently logged in with a
valid > > session > > > > using what > > > > are now invalidated credentials.
This user continues to have > > access > > > to > > > > the UI > > > > until
its session is invalidated. The real world situation would > > be > > > if > >
> > someone > > > > was getting their privileges revoked for the admin account
due to > > > > termination > > > > and the password had to be changed. If this
user still had a > > session > > > > open on > > > > its browser it would
still be able to configure parts of the > > system > > > > including > > > >
policies and account access. > >

Originally posted on 2011-07-27 20:22:32 by admin
An additional thought to Vika's point - most enterprises use the IdM to
enforce password resets.  We should probably consider the following:

  
1) If a user attempts to log into Eucalyptus using the IdM but their password
has expired, do we allow them to log into Eucalyptus WebUI?  Do we allow them
to change their password from the Eucalyptus WebUI as an interface to the IdM?
Do we provide an error page, letting them know that their login is no longer
valid and have them talk to the systems administrator (e.g. cloud
administrator)?

  
2) If we don't leverage the Enterprise IdM, do we offer password enforcement
inside of Eucalyptus?
